title: Quiz 2: Transport & Defense Systems
description: Assessment covering The Blood, Cardiovascular System, and Lymphatic System (Chapters 4-6). Focuses on cardiac physiology, circulation, immunity foundations, and related pathologies.

questions.question: Trace the path of a red blood cell through the heart, starting from the Superior Vena Cava.
questions.explanation: Deoxygenated blood enters the Right Atrium -> Tricuspid Valve -> Right Ventricle -> Pulmonary Valve -> Pulmonary Artery -> Lungs -> Oxygenated blood returns via Pulmonary Veins -> Left Atrium.
questions.hint: Remember: Right side pumps to lungs, Left side pumps to body.

questions.question: Which component of the cardiac conduction system is known as the natural 'pacemaker' of the heart because it has the fastest intrinsic firing rate?
questions.explanation: The SA node initiates the electrical impulse that sets the heart rate (sinus rhythm), normally firing at 60-100 bpm.
questions.hint: It is located in the wall of the right atrium.

questions.question: Match the blood cell type with its primary function:
questions.explanation: Erythrocytes (Red cells) carry gas. Neutrophils are first-responder phagocytes. Platelets patch leaks. Lymphocytes handle specific immune responses.
questions.hint: Think about what is needed for clotting vs breathing vs fighting infection.

questions.question: Review the clinical scenario below. Which condition is the patient likely suffering from?

richContent.content:
Patient Assessment:
A 65-year-old male presents with breathlessness (dyspnoea), especially when lying flat (orthopnoea), and coughing up frothy sputum. Auscultation reveals crackles in the lungs.

questions.explanation: Left ventricular failure causes blood to back up into the pulmonary circulation, increasing pressure in pulmonary capillaries and forcing fluid into alveoli (pulmonary oedema), causing breathlessness. Right-sided failure typically causes systemic oedema (swollen legs).
questions.hint: The fluid is backing up into the lungs.

questions.question: The volume of blood pumped out by one ventricle with each beat is called the ___BLANK___. This value multiplied by the heart rate equals the ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: Stroke Volume (SV) is per beat (~70mL). Cardiac Output (CO) is per minute (SV x HR).
questions.hint: Think about a 'single stroke' vs the total 'output'.

questions.question: Which of the following factors would INCREASE blood pressure? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: BP = Cardiac Output x Peripheral Resistance. Vasoconstriction increases resistance. Increased CO increases flow. RAAS retains fluid and constricts vessels. Parasympathetic activity lowers HR and BP.
questions.hint: Think about what makes the heart work harder or squeezes the vessels.

questions.question: What is the specific name of the fetal blood vessel that allows blood to bypass the non-functional lungs by shunting blood from the pulmonary artery directly to the aorta?
questions.explanation: The ductus arteriosus connects the pulmonary artery to the aorta in the fetus. The foramen ovale connects the atria. The ductus venosus bypasses the liver.
questions.hint: It connects two 'arteries' (arteriosus).

questions.question: Match the layer of the blood vessel wall with its tissue composition:
questions.explanation: Intima = inner lining. Media = muscle/elasticity (control diameter). Adventitia = outer support/protection.
questions.hint: Media is in the middle and does the muscle work.

questions.question: In the capillary bed, which force acts to PUSH fluid OUT of the capillary into the tissue spaces at the arterial end?

richContent.content:
End of CapillaryHydrostatic PressureOsmotic Pressure
Arterial End35 mmHg25 mmHg
Venous End15 mmHg25 mmHg

questions.explanation: Hydrostatic pressure (blood pressure) pushes fluid out. Osmotic pressure (generated by plasma proteins like albumin) pulls fluid back in. At the arterial end, hydrostatic pressure is higher.
questions.hint: Think of the pressure generated by the heart pumping.

questions.question: Which of the following are functions of the Lymphatic System? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Return excess tissue fluid to the blood
Absorb and transport fats from the digestive system (lacteals)
Filter blood to remove old red blood cells
Provide sites for maturation and proliferation of lymphocytes

questions.explanation: The lymphatic system drains tissue fluid, absorbs fats (via lacteals), and supports immunity. The spleen (a lymphoid organ) filters blood, but the system as a whole does not. Oxygen transport is the job of the cardiovascular system.
questions.hint: Think drainage, defense, and digestion (fats).

questions.question: The hepatic portal vein carries oxygenated blood from the heart directly to the liver.
questions.explanation: FALSE. The hepatic portal vein carries VENOUS (deoxygenated) blood rich in nutrients from the digestive organs to the liver for processing. The Hepatic ARTERY carries oxygenated blood.
questions.hint: Does 'portal' imply a direct connection to the heart or a detour?

questions.question: What is the primary function of the QRS complex seen on an ECG trace?
questions.explanation: P wave = Atrial depolarisation. QRS complex = Ventricular depolarisation (contraction). T wave = Ventricular repolarisation (relaxation).
questions.hint: This is the largest spike on the ECG, corresponding to the most powerful contraction.

questions.question: Arrange the steps of the haemostasis (blood clotting) mechanism in the correct order.
questions.explanation: Vessel constricts -> Platelets stick -> Clotting cascade leads to Prothrombin activator -> Thrombin -> Fibrin mesh (clot).
questions.hint: The physical plug happens before the chemical cascade finishes.

questions.question: Which blood type is considered the 'Universal Donor' for red blood cells?
questions.explanation: Type O erythrocytes have no antigens on their surface (no A or B), so they generally do not trigger an immune reaction in recipients. (Specifically O Negative).
questions.hint: This type has zerO antigens.

questions.question: Match the type of shock with its underlying cause:

pairs.right: Severe infection causing systemic inflammation and vasodilation

questions.explanation: Hypovolaemic=Volume loss. Cardiogenic=Heart failure. Anaphylactic=Allergy. Septic=Infection.
questions.hint: Look at the roots of the words: 'Hypo-vol', 'Cardio', 'Septic'.

questions.question: Which of the following are mechanisms that aid venous return to the heart? (Select all that apply)

options.text: High pressure from the left ventricle

questions.explanation: Venous pressure is low. Return is assisted by muscle contractions squeezing veins, valves preventing backflow, thoracic pressure changes during breathing, and gravity (from above the heart).
questions.hint: Blood in veins is under very low pressure, so it needs external help.

questions.question: The hormone ___BLANK___ is produced by the kidneys in response to hypoxia and stimulates the red bone marrow to produce erythrocytes.
questions.explanation: Erythropoietin (EPO) regulates red blood cell production.
questions.hint: Often abbreviated as EPO.

questions.question: What is the main physiological difference between Atherosclerosis and Arteriosclerosis?

options.text: They are exactly the same condition
Atherosclerosis involves plaque formation; Arteriosclerosis involves hardening/loss of elasticity
Arteriosclerosis affects veins; Atherosclerosis affects arteries
Atherosclerosis is caused by aging only; Arteriosclerosis is caused by diet only

questions.explanation: Atherosclerosis is a specific type of arteriosclerosis caused by lipid plaques (atheroma). Arteriosclerosis is a general term for hardening/stiffening of arteries, often age-related.
questions.hint: Atheroma = Plaque (fatty porridge). Sclerosis = Hardening.

questions.question: What is the term for the iron-containing protein in red blood cells that binds to oxygen?
questions.explanation: Haemoglobin is the pigment that carries oxygen.
questions.hint: Starts with 'H'.

questions.question: Select the risk factors for Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) known as Virchow's Triad. (Select three)
questions.explanation: Virchow's Triad consists of: 1. Stasis (slow flow), 2. Hypercoagulability (thick blood), 3. Vessel wall injury.
questions.hint: Think about what makes a clot likely: stopped flow, sticky blood, or a rough surface.

questions.question: Match the pulse point with its anatomical location:
questions.explanation: Radial=Radius/Wrist. Carotid=Neck. Brachial=Arm. Popliteal=Knee. Dorsalis Pedis=Foot.
questions.hint: Think about the bone names associated with these locations.

questions.question: Arrange the steps of the Renin-Angiotensin-Aldosterone System (RAAS) in response to low blood pressure.

items.text: Renin converts Angiotensinogen to Angiotensin I
ACE converts Angiotensin I to Angiotensin II
Kidneys retain Sodium and Water, raising BP

questions.explanation: Low BP -> Renin -> Angiotensin I -> (ACE) -> Angiotensin II -> Aldosterone -> Na+/Water retention -> Increased BP.
questions.hint: It starts in the kidneys and ends with kidney action.

questions.question: Which large lymphatic vessel drains lymph from the entire lower body, left arm, and left side of the head/neck?
questions.explanation: The Thoracic Duct drains about 75% of the body's lymph. The Right Lymphatic Duct only drains the upper right quadrant.
questions.hint: This duct is much larger than the Right Lymphatic Duct.

questions.question: A thrombus is a moving blood clot, while an embolus is a stationary blood clot.
questions.explanation: FALSE. Definitions are reversed. A Thrombus is stationary (fixed to vessel wall). An Embolus is moving (travels in the bloodstream).
questions.hint: Think 'Thrombus = Stuck', 'Embolus = Embarking/Moving'.

questions.question: Which of the following are causes of Oedema (swelling)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Oedema is caused by forces pushing fluid out (hydrostatic pressure), reduced forces pulling it in (low osmotic pressure), leaky vessels, or blocked drainage.
questions.hint: Think about what forces fluid out of capillaries or prevents it from draining.

questions.question: What is the name of the largest artery in the body?
questions.explanation: The aorta is the main artery leaving the left ventricle.
questions.hint: Starts with 'A'.

questions.question: In the context of the cardiac cycle, what does 'Preload' refer to?

options.text: The pressure the heart must pump against (resistance)
The degree of stretch of the ventricular muscle fibers at the end of diastole

questions.explanation: Preload is the volume/stretch inside the ventricle right before it contracts (End Diastolic Volume). Afterload is the resistance it pumps against.
questions.hint: Think 'Pre' = Before contraction (filling).

questions.question: What is the function of the spleen in the lymphatic and circulatory systems?

options.text: To filter lymph and trap bacteria
To filter blood, remove old red blood cells, and store platelets

questions.explanation: The spleen filters BLOOD, not lymph. It recycles iron from old RBCs, stores platelets/blood, and facilitates immune responses.
questions.hint: It is often called the 'graveyard' for red blood cells.

questions.question: The three arteries branching off the aortic arch are the Brachiocephalic artery, the Left Common Carotid artery, and the ___BLANK___ artery.
questions.explanation: The three branches are Brachiocephalic (right side), Left Common Carotid, and Left Subclavian.
questions.hint: It goes under the collarbone on the left side.

questions.question: Which mechanism primarily controls blood pressure on a moment-to-moment basis (short term)?
questions.explanation: Baroreceptors (pressure sensors in carotid/aorta) detect changes instantly and signal the brain to adjust heart rate and vessel diameter via the autonomic nervous system. RAAS is long-term.
questions.hint: Which one uses nerves for a fast response?
